snippet: By the time the U.S. withdrew from Iraq, it thought it had subdued the Islamic State. The group is now on a very different trajectory.
abstract: Rise of Islamic State in space of few short years has led to international soul-searching over who is to blame for group's growing strength, but reasons are complex and counter many long-held assumptions; Iraq War, Syria's civil war and conditions unintentionally created by American forces and allies all factor in ISIS's ascendancy; expansion of terrorist attacks outside borders of Iraq and Syria have Western leaders questioning what can be done (Series: State of Terror).

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Anne Barnard and Hwaida Saad from Beirut, Lebanon; Richard A. Oppel Jr., Stephen Farrell and Nicholas Kulish from New York; Matthew Rosenberg, Mark Mazzetti, Matt Apuzzo and Eric Schmitt from Washington; and C. J. Chivers.

lead_paragraph: By the time the U.S. withdrew from Iraq, it thought it had subdued the Islamic State. The group is now on a very different trajectory.

headline.print_headline: In Rise of ISIS, Many Strands of Blame
headline.main: In Rise of ISIS, No Single Missed Key but Many Strands of Blame
